Award.AwardTitle: ELT Collaborative Research: Beyond the boring billion: Late Proterozoic glaciation, oxygenation and the proliferation of complex life
Award.AbstractNarration:
ELT Collaborative Research: Beyond the Boring Billion: Late Proterozoic Glaciation, Oxygenation and the Proliferation of Complex Life

by

Timothy Lyons, Univ. California, Riverside, EAR-1338299
Nicholas Planavsky, Dartmouth College, EAR-1338208
Christopher Reinhard, Georgia Tech, EAR-1338290

ABSTRACT
The middle chapters in Earth's history, roughly 1.8 to 0.8 billion years ago, were defined by remarkable stability in generally low but persistent oxygen levels in the ocean and atmosphere and stifled development of early organisms for a billion years. How and when this cycle was broken are among the central unanswered questions in the history of life on Earth. The eventual rise to higher oxygen levels and ultimately the appearance of animals correspond generally with history's most extreme climatic events and mountain building episodes, and the timing and cause-and-effect relationships among all these events and processes are frontiers ripe for study. To this end, we will construct an unusually comprehensive chemical data set for rocks from Australia and Arctic Canada deposited directly within the transition between the stable 'boring' billion and the major milestones that followed.

The onset of global-scale glaciation 0.7 to 0.8 billion years ago is without question one of the most dramatic environmental transitions in Earth history, and the generally synchronous radiation of eukaryotic organisms, with greater complexity than their microbial ancestors, and the emergence of animals are among the most remarkable evolutionary events in the long history of life. The proposed multidisciplinary team will illuminate the timing of these key events and their likely links to Earth's oxygenation, while probing the cause-and-effect relationships among biological innovation, oxygen, and the onset of global-scale glaciation. The study's full range of impacts will reach far beyond the intrinsic scientific merit, including high-level research opportunities for the diverse undergraduate populations at all three institutions. We will also reach out into the community through sponsorship of science fair projects and through many different contributions to the new Riverside STEM Academy, including organization of a lecture series that will bring prominent scientists and engineers into the school. The study also includes plans for collaborative mentoring of graduate students, including student exchanges, and is an important step in the early careers of two new professors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of this project was to improve our understanding of the links between environmental and biotic evolution. More specifically, we set out to test the idea that the rise of animals and complex ecosystems characterized by a significant ecological role for predation were linked to a rise in surface oxygen levels. During the grant period, we provided evidence for markedly low atmospheric oxygen levels through most of Earth’s history, until 800 million years ago. Our work suggests that atmospheric oxygen levels for much of Earth’s history were below oft-cited 'threshold' values of oxygen required by early-evolving animals, in contrast with the traditional view of a much earlier rise in atmospheric oxygen. Using a modeling approach, we built from our empirical work on the geologic record of background surface oxygen levels and provided support for the idea that, on seasonal timescales, the shallow oceans in Earth’s past would have been characterized by hypoxic conditions that were toxic to animals and algae, again supporting the idea that there was a direct link between oxygen levels and the rise of complex life. We found evidence for a rise of surface oxygen levels coincident with evidence for a shift in ecosystem complexity and the earliest estimates for the timing of animal emergence. Additionally, we proposed that this Earth state was stable on a billion-year time scale because of geochemical feedbacks that operated in a largely anoxic ocean—providing a mechanistic explanation for how Earth could remain in a low-oxygen condition for such an extended period.

 More broadly, this project has resulted in the training of a large, diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. Students involved in this project gained skills in isotope geochemistry that are applicable to a wide range of research in the Earth sciences, as well as to a broad group of other STEM fields. Further, as most of the students trained during the course of this work are from groups underrepresented in Earth sciences, this grant helped to increase the diversity of potential isotope geochemists in the workforce. Lastly, beyond academic publications, the results and core ideas of this project have been disseminated to the broader community through numerous articles for the general public and a PBS-supported educational program. Through these efforts we were able to share ideas on environmental and biotic co-evolution with a large number (currently estimated to be >1 million) people. Our goal was for these efforts to raise public interest in science, increase societal knowledge, and helped provide a framework for people to properly evaluate global climate change on a range of time scales (in the past, present, and future).
